regionLanguage.title: Region, Language and Time Zone
regionLanguage.selectInteractively: Select language settings interactively during Windows Setup
regionLanguage.installWithSettings: Install Windows using these language settings
regionLanguage.uiLanguageDesc: Windows features like Settings and File Explorer will appear in this language. It must match the language of your Windows 10/11 .iso file.
regionLanguage.firstLanguageDesc: The first language will also determine the initial regional format, which defines how numbers, dates, times and currency are formatted.
regionLanguage.selectLanguageInSetup: Select language settings during Windows Setup
regionLanguage.selectLanguageInSetupDesc: If enabled, language settings will be selected interactively during Windows Setup. If disabled, the language settings below will be used.
regionLanguage.autoSetTimeZoneDesc: If enabled, Windows will determine your time zone based on language and region settings. If disabled, you can set a specific time zone below.
regionLanguage.timeZoneImplicit: Let Windows determine your time zone based on language and region settings
regionLanguage.timeZoneExplicitDesc: This is useful when your country or region spans multiple time zones, like Australia or the United States.

setupSettings.title: Setup settings
setupSettings.bypassRequirementsDesc: Bypass TPM, Secure Boot, RAM, and CPU requirements for Windows 11 installation.
setupSettings.bypassNetworkDesc: Only check this if your computer really does not have internet access. You will still need to click "I don't have internet" during Setup. If you just want to create local accounts, use the User accounts section instead.
setupSettings.useConfigurationSet: Use a distribution share / configuration set
setupSettings.useConfigurationSetDesc: Windows Setup will look for a folder named $OEM$ in the root of the drive where autounattend.xml is located and copy its contents to the target partition.
setupSettings.hidePowerShell: Hide any PowerShell windows during Setup
setupSettings.hidePowerShellDesc: PowerShell scripts will run with the -WindowStyle Hidden switch. Do not enable if you use interactive prompts (like Read-Host) in your scripts, as you won't be able to answer them without a visible window.
setupSettings.keepSensitiveFilesDesc: By default, files like unattend.xml and Wifi.xml which may contain sensitive data will be deleted once Windows Setup finishes. Enable this to keep those files.
setupSettings.useNarratorDesc: Narrator is a built-in screen reader that speaks out loud what is on your screen. It will start during Windows Setup and after logon.

nameAccount.title: Name and Account
nameAccount.computerNameRandom: Let Windows generate a random computer name like DESKTOP-ZFAH8Z2
nameAccount.computerNameScript: Provide a Windows PowerShell script to set the computer name dynamically
nameAccount.userAccountsUnattended: Let Windows Setup create the following local ("offline") accounts
nameAccount.userAccountsInteractiveMicrosoft: Add a Microsoft ("online") user account interactively during Windows Setup
nameAccount.userAccountsInteractiveLocal: Add a local ("offline") user account interactively during Windows Setup
nameAccount.accountListDesc: Leave Display name empty unless you want it to be different from Account name.
nameAccount.firstLogonDesc: Several settings will only be applied when an administrator logs on for the first time. Choose which account to use for this.
nameAccount.logonOwnAccount: Logon to the first administrator account created above
nameAccount.logonBuiltinAdmin: Activate built-in account "Administrator" and logon to this account
nameAccount.logonNoneDesc: The installation ends with the sign-in screen being shown. Not recommended.
nameAccount.obscurePasswords: Obscure all account passwords with Base64
nameAccount.obscurePasswordsDesc: Encode passwords in your autounattend.xml file with Base64 encoding for basic obfuscation.
nameAccount.passwordExpirationDesc: These settings only apply to local accounts. The password of the built-in "Administrator" account never expires.
nameAccount.passwordUnlimitedDesc: This is in accordance to NIST guidelines that no longer recommend password expiration.
nameAccount.lockoutDefaultDesc: Windows will lock out an account after 10 failed logon attempts within 10 minutes. After 10 minutes, the account is unlocked automatically.
nameAccount.lockoutDisabledDesc: Warning: Disabling Account Lockout might leave your computer vulnerable to brute-force attacks.

partitioning.title: Partitioning and formatting
partitioning.interactive: Partition the disk interactively during Windows Setup
partitioning.automatic: Let Windows Setup wipe, partition and format your hard drive (more specifically, disk 0) using these settings
partitioning.custom: Use a custom diskpart script to configure your disk(s)
partitioning.gptDesc: The GPT partition layout must be used for UEFI systems.
partitioning.mbrDesc: The MBR-based partition layout must be used for legacy BIOS systems.
partitioning.windowsRe: Choose how to install Windows RE
partitioning.windowsReDesc: Windows 24H2 seems to ignore this setting and will always create a recovery partition with a minimum size of 600 MB.
partitioning.reFolderDesc: This will install Windows RE in C:\Recovery. No recovery partition will be created.
partitioning.reNoneDesc: This will delete the C:\Recovery folder and thus free about 600 MB of disk space. No recovery partition will be created.
partitioning.recoverySizeDesc: Set the size for the Windows RE recovery partition (minimum 300 MB recommended)
partitioning.diskpartScriptDesc: Drive letter assignments in the script (e.g. ASSIGN LETTER=W) solely affect the Windows PE stage of Windows Setup; these assignments do not persist to the new installation.
partitioning.installTo: Choose partition to install Windows to
partitioning.installToAvailable: Install Windows to the first available partition that has enough space and does not already contain an installation of Windows
partitioning.diskAssertionDesc: When you let Windows Setup partition your disks unattendedly, there is a risk they were assigned unexpected index numbers. In rare cases, disk 0 does not refer to your primary hard drive, but rather your USB thumb drive. You can provide VBScript code to check the assigned disk index numbers. If your script returns with WScript.Quit 1, Windows Setup will halt to avoid data loss.
partitioning.diskAssertionScript: Run this VBScript code to check disk layout

windowsEdition.title: Windows edition
windowsEdition.genericDesc: Such a key can be used to install Windows, but will not activate it. You can change the product key later.
windowsEdition.interactive: Enter a product key interactively during Windows Setup
windowsEdition.interactiveDesc: You can also enter your key in the autounattend.xml file yourself to avoid disclosing it. To do so, find the <Key>00000-00000-00000-00000-00000</Key> element and replace the text with your own key.
windowsEdition.firmware: Use product key stored in BIOS/UEFI firmware
windowsEdition.firmwareDesc: Choose this if your computer came pre-installed with Windows and you want to reuse that license.
windowsEdition.sourceImageDesc: Run Get-WindowsImage -ImagePath "...\install.wim" in PowerShell to learn the name and index of an image inside a .wim file.
windowsEdition.selectByKey: Select image according to the product key

wifi.title: WLAN / Wi-Fi setup
wifi.interactive: Configure Wi-Fi interactively during Windows Setup
wifi.skipDesc: Choose this if you have a wired connection to the internet.
wifi.fromProfile: Configure Wi-Fi using an XML file created by netsh.exe wlan export profile key=clear on another computer
wifi.wpa3Note: If both your Wi-Fi router and your computer's Wi-Fi adapter support it, make sure to select WPA3. Otherwise, Windows Setup will try to switch from WPA2 to WPA3 and require manual interaction.
wifi.passwordNote: You should not enter your actual Wi-Fi password here. Once you have downloaded the autounattend.xml file, find the password enclosed in <keyMaterial>â€¦</keyMaterial> and adjust it.

advancedSettings.title: Advanced Settings
advancedSettings.compactOSDefault: Let Windows decide whether to use Compact OS
advancedSettings.peDefault: Let Windows Setup (setup.exe) handle the Windows PE stage as usual
advancedSettings.peGenerated: Generate a .cmd script using the form's other settings and also these options
advancedSettings.peScript: Use a custom .cmd script to handle the Windows PE stage
advancedSettings.disable8dot3Desc: This removes all existing short file names such as PROGRA~1 and disables the creation of new ones.
advancedSettings.pauseFormatting: Pause before disk is partitioned and formatted
advancedSettings.pauseReboot: Pause before Windows Setup reboots at the end of the Windows PE stage
advancedSettings.customPeScriptDesc: Your script has to partition and format the disk, copy a Windows image to it and make it bootable. Note that PowerShell is usually not available in Windows PE.
advancedSettings.vmSupportDesc: Make sure to check the usage notes for how to properly configure your VM.
advancedSettings.virtioGuestTools: Install VirtIO Guest Tools and QEMU Guest Agent (e.g. for Proxmox VE)
advancedSettings.parallelsTools: Install Parallels Tools for Parallels Desktop
advancedSettings.wdacDesc: Applications in C:\Windows, C:\Program Files and C:\Program Files (x86) are allowed to run. Applications stored elsewhere and those in known user-writable folders are not allowed to run. To disable this WDAC policy later, simply delete the file C:\Windows\System32\CodeIntegrity\CiPolicies\Active\{d26bff32-33a2-48a3-b037-10357ee48427}.cip and reboot.
advancedSettings.wdacConfigure: Configure a basic WDAC policy using these settings
advancedSettings.wdacEnforcement: Choose how to enforce the policy
advancedSettings.wdacAuditDesc: Logs drivers and applications that would have been blocked.
advancedSettings.wdacAuditBootFailureDesc: When the policy blocks a system driver and thus would prevent Windows from booting, use audit mode. Otherwise, use enforcement mode.
advancedSettings.wdacEnforcementDesc: Drivers and applications will be blocked unless allowed by the policy.
advancedSettings.wdacScriptRestrictedDesc: PowerShell will run in Constrained Language Mode.

uiPersonalization.title: UI and Personalization
uiPersonalization.showFileExtensionsDesc: By default, File Explorer would hide extensions for known file types.
uiPersonalization.launchToThisPC: Open File Explorer to This PC instead of Quick access
uiPersonalization.disableBingResults: Do not show Bing results when searching in the Start menu or the search box
uiPersonalization.classicContextMenu: Use classic context (right-click) menu in Windows 11
uiPersonalization.showEndTask: Show End task command in the taskbar
uiPersonalization.hideFiles: Choose which files are hidden in File Explorer
uiPersonalization.hideFilesDefaultDesc: This will hide any file that has the Hidden attribute set.
uiPersonalization.hideFilesHiddenSystemDesc: This will only hide files that have both the Hidden and the System attribute set.
uiPersonalization.hideFilesNoneDesc: This setting is recommended for advanced users.
uiPersonalization.hideTaskViewButton: Hide the Task view button from the taskbar
uiPersonalization.taskbarSearch: Choose how to display the search box in the taskbar
uiPersonalization.startTilesDefaultDesc: If you select apps in the Remove bloatware section below, Windows 10 will automatically remove their tiles from the Start menu.
uiPersonalization.startTilesCustom: Configure tiles using an XML file
uiPersonalization.startPinsDefaultDesc: Avoid this setting if you select apps in the Remove bloatware section below, as Windows 11 will deceptively retain their pins in the Start menu.
uiPersonalization.startPinsCustom: Configure pins using a JSON file created by PowerShell's Export-StartLayout cmdlet
uiPersonalization.visualEffectsDefault: Use default settings chosen by Windows
uiPersonalization.controlAnimations: Animate controls and elements inside windows
uiPersonalization.animateMinMax: Animate windows when minimizing and maximizing
uiPersonalization.menuAnimation: Fade or slide menus into view
uiPersonalization.tooltipAnimation: Fade or slide ToolTips into view
uiPersonalization.selectionFade: Fade out menu items after clicking
uiPersonalization.listviewShadow: Use drop shadows for icon labels on the desktop
uiPersonalization.foldersStartDefault: Show default folders on Start next to the Power button
uiPersonalization.foldersStartDesc: This setting has no effect on Windows 10. On Windows 11, the folders will appear on the Start menu.
uiPersonalization.personalizationDesc: These settings are particularly useful if you want to use Windows without activation when the Personalization settings page is not available.
uiPersonalization.systemColorTheme: Choose color theme for taskbar and Start menu
uiPersonalization.accentColorOnStart: Show accent color on Start menu and taskbar
uiPersonalization.accentColorOnBorders: Show accent color on title bars and window borders
uiPersonalization.wallpaperScript: Provide a Windows PowerShell script to load a desktop wallpaper image
uiPersonalization.wallpaperScriptDesc: Your script will be evaluated during Windows Setup, after your computer has connected to a network. The script must return a byte[] value, which must contain the image data.
uiPersonalization.lockScreenScript: Provide a Windows PowerShell script to load the lock screen image
uiPersonalization.lockScreenScriptDesc: Your script will be evaluated during Windows Setup, after your computer has connected to a network. The script must return a byte[] value, which must contain the image data.

accessibility.title: Accessibility Settings
accessibility.lockKeysSkip: Use default lock key states and behaviors
accessibility.lockKeysConfigure: Configure the initial state and behavior of lock keys as follows
accessibility.lockKeyConfigDesc: This will affect all users and also the login screen.
accessibility.stickyKeysHotKeyActive: Press the Shift key 5 times to turn Sticky keys on or off
accessibility.stickyKeysHotKeySound: Play a siren sound when Sticky keys are turned on or off by using the Shift key
accessibility.stickyKeysIndicator: Show the Sticky keys icon on the taskbar
accessibility.stickyKeysAudibleFeedback: Play a sound when shortcut keys are pressed and released
accessibility.stickyKeysTriState: Lock shortcut keys when pressed twice in a row
accessibility.stickyKeysTwoKeysOff: Turn off Sticky keys when two keys are pressed at the same time
accessibility.stickyKeysDesc: This will affect all users and also the login screen.

customScripts.title: Run custom scripts
customScripts.systemScriptsDesc: These scripts will run in the system context, before user accounts are created.
customScripts.defaultUserScriptsDesc: Use these scripts to modify the default user's registry hive.
customScripts.firstLogonScriptsDesc: These scripts will run when the first user logs on after Windows has been installed.
customScripts.userOnceScriptsDesc: These scripts will run whenever a user logs on for the first time.
customScripts.restartExplorer: Restart File Explorer after scripts have run

xmlMarkup.title: XML markup for more components
xmlMarkup.description: You can add settings for all available components to add functionality not yet covered by this generator.
